_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Facility maintains two separate ammonia refrigeration systems which contain a total of approximately 23,200 pounds of ammonia: 16,200 pounds in the South System and 7,000 pounds in the North System. The systems are closed loops, and little or no ammonia is needed annually to replenish minor losses due to routine maintenance or to sustain a milk and nut cooler, a 0 degree F freezer unit, plant process water coolers, and Facility air conditioners.



The receiver tanks for both systems are equipped with both sight glasses and pressure gauges.  The pressure relief valve setting on the tanks is 250  psig, and the vent is to the roof.  The mechanical rooms where the receivers are located are equipped with ammonia sensors.  At 30 ppm the sensors activate emergency exhaust fans.  At 50 ppm the sensors activate plant wide alarms and the system compressors are automatically shut down.  Shutdown allows the ammonia in the system to migrate to the cold spots within the system.  The sensors are replaced when required.  The sensors are zero adjusted every 90 days and span adjusted and calibrated every 6 months.

 

Upon activation of the ammonia detection alarm, employees are to proceed to the employee cafeteria.  Personnel have been instructed to wait for further instructions from plant management.



Both refrigeration systems are visually inspected daily. In addition to the ammonia sensors,there are either equipment electric panel lights or computer monitoring readings for temperature, pressure and/or liquid level on all pressurized elements of the systems. Vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves vented to the roof of the building. An ammonia dump fire access panel is mounted on the exterior wall

of each mechanical room. A fire hose can be affixed to the panel, and the ammonia charge can be dumped and mixed with water on discharge.



An emergency action plan has been developed and has been coordinated with the Abilene Fire Department. The Facility has an arrange

ment with the Abilene Fire Department to provide response in emergencies. The Abiline Fire Department has been made familiar with the Facility and the ammonia refrigeration systems.



Russell Stover has a proven record of safety to prevent releases, and has not has any release within the last five years that resulted in any onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage.  Russell Stover employees' utilize a professional approach to prevent accidents by improving operations, engineering, and training whenever possible.  Russell Stover is committed to continuously evaluate the ammonia refrigeration systems as required under the PSM and RMP process standards to ensure safe operations.
